title: Mr forfee
author: Mr forfee
content: We need to know that crypto doesn't perform any magic. If the country is poor, the government should help its citizens  upgrade to a certain level where they can help themselves.If you live in a poor country, how can you afford to buy crypto to help someone? Crypto isn't always the answer to everything. For some, spending a little on cheap coins might pay off, and they might have a big success story, but that’s not always the case. Crypto doesn't end poverty, in fact, it can make you poorer if you don't know what you're doing.  if you have the right knowledge and resources, it can help you make a lot of money.

For some, spending a little on cheap coins might pay off, and they might have a big success story, but that’s not always the case. Crypto doesn't end poverty, in fact, it can make you poorer if you don't know what you're doing.  if you have the right knowledge and resources, it can help you make a lot of money.You have actually answered your question which means you already know that Bitcoin cannot help  a poor nation much if they fail to put certain things in place that will actually change their status. Bitcoin need money to start even if the government want to go into mining, they still need capital to building the mining farm and other infrastructures. Buying and holding equally need money which poor nations cannot afford especially when they are unable to meet their basic needs. Some may think that a nation can borrow to make investment in Bitcoin but that is not advisable because you don't know if the investment will be able to generate enough profits to settle the loan before the tenure. Therefore, poor nations have more things to worry about than investing in Bitcoin.

Productivity drives growth through satisfaction of people's want, both local and international, because after meeting local demands, you can export and bring in foreign exchange.

comments.body: We can see how many countries have been adopting cryptocurrency recently. Alot of them are now making their own reserves as a means to facilitate their economy. Personally I wish more countries would partake in this, as it's a good idea. Like op said, crypto isn't magic, you invest your money and when the market pumps, you make money. Opposite thing happens when there is a dump.

comments.author: Nwada001
comments.body: Quote from: Mr forfee on March 04, 2025, 09:18:32 AMCrypto doesn't end poverty, in fact, it can make you poorer if you don't know what you're doing.  if you have the right knowledge and resources, it can help you make a lot of money.Cryptocurrency investment is a two-way thing; if you rush in without having the right knowledge and understanding of how it works, you rush out with an empty pocket, and even if you also go in with the best knowledge, there is also a possibility that you will come out with almost an empty pocket. Chasing after instant profit doesn't always end well; the moment you see altcoin as a means to escape poverty, your chance of also ending up poor is very high.You can also invest in Bitcoin for those who already have a fortune and make a profit from it after holding it for a long period of time, but you still won't be able to take yourself from the poverty status up to the rich people's standard. You invest in hundreds; your profit will come out in hundreds if you hold for circles, same with other figures.

Opposite thing happens when there is a dump.As of now, El Salvador is the only country to add bitcoin to its national reserves. The remaining countries such as the United States, Brazil...are only considering this idea, but no country has made a final decision yet. Honestly, adding bitcoin and cryptocurrencies to the national reserves would be a huge benefit to the crypto industry as it would boost its price and popularity. But I don't think that will facilitate and boost their economy and that may be why they are not in a hurry to add bitcoin to their national reserves. Many investors support this idea because it benefits them but to be fair, crypto assets including bitcoin are too volatile and this is not considered an advantage or will have a positive impact on the national economy.

comments.author: OgNasty
comments.body: I don't think Bitcoin alone can fix what is wrong with a poor country, but it can help by solving the problem of inflation.  Unfortunately, most of those poor countries are poor from the government terrorizing their people with inflation, so that sort of takes a page from their playbook.  El Salvador is a good example though of what a country can achieve if they crack down on crime, start supporting their citizens, and provide them with a form of money they can trust.  Other countries are certainly watching and taking notes.

comments.author: nakamura12
comments.body: As you have said, bitcoin doesn't end poverty so the answer is No, bitcoin can't help a poor country or nation. You have answered your own question if you ask me. To be exact, not all countries have the financial stability to spend on crypto which may help them to earn profit. Even though a country is poor but people who live in that country can still buy bitcoin little by little until they can acquire the amount of bitcoin they want but still it won't help the country get out of poverty.

comments.author: Deegodstime
comments.body: Apart from the roles played by citizens in eradicating poverty in any country, it's the governments duties to utilize the countries resources and manage it appropriately in other to reduce the rate of poverty in the country. Bitcoin is not our government so it can't help a country eradicate poverty. Bitcoin can not do the work of the government, it can only help citizens gain financial stability and strength but can't do the job of the government.
